description.narrative: Stop Child Labor (SCL) is an international coalition working with organizations in Asia, Africa and Latin America that share its aim and promote child labor free zones where inhabitants agree to eliminate child labor together. It convinces businesses and CSR initiatives of the need to eliminate child labor and, where possible, collaborates with them. SCL’s innovative ‘Getting down to Business’ program combines efforts from both sides: top down (certifying and verifying supply chain actors) as well as bottom up (creating area-based child labour free zones). SCL believes that this combined approach can be a sustainable solution to help eradicate all forms of child labor and create and maintain responsible business practices.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs The Netherlands

title.narrative: Key stakeholders have promoted and supported the community-based approach by convincing companies and CSR initiatives to undertake action at a regional and (inter)national level.

description.narrative: Key stakeholders are: (national governments/local authorities, (inter)governmental organisations and international organizations)

title.narrative: 2.1 Number of (international) organizations and/or local authorities that are including the CLFZ approach or related strategies on child labour in their policies/tools and/or support activities/projects in that context.

comment.narrative: The Stop Child Labour coalition was able to inspire and exchange with many others through her partner networks during the Global Child Labour Conference in Argentina in November 2017 and was pleased to see the inclusions in the Final Declaration of the GCLC the recognition of the importance of area-based and community interventions for eradicating child labour. Besides these results SCL has also been able to inspire different new local organisations in Mali, Uganda and India to adopt the CLFZ approach. For further information on results in inspiring and influencing other organisations and/or authorities see the SCL Annual Report 2017-2018. Final update, based on final reporting for GTDB is expected in September 2019.

title.narrative: 2.3 Further steps towards an effective inclusion of anti-child labour measures in public procurement have been taken by the Dutch national government and local authorities.

description.narrative: 1 = Public acknowledgement by government of importance of including anti-child labour measures in public procurement 2 = Present policy on sustainable public procurement which recognizes the OECD Guidelines as the basic framework for the International Social Criteria (Internationale Sociale Voorwaarden -ISV) in public procurement, with a menu that is optional on ISV, including anti-child labour measures, for municipalities 3 = Improved implementation – to be assessed in a narrative in terms of context, inputs/activities and results – of the ISV including anti-child labour measures by the central and local governments in particular municipalities (through political lobby and participation in procurement pilots in the context of the ICSR covenant for the natural stone sector). 4 = Standard inclusion of anti-child labour measures in all public tenders of the central government and local governments (in particular municipalities)

comment.narrative: SCL coalition partner ICN participated in different learning sessions with Dutch municipalities as part of the larger pilot on including ‘Internationale Sociale Voorwaarden’ policy in public procurement of natural stone). Furthermore, concrete input was provided by ICN to one of the municipalities on one of their main projects in the city centre. For more information, see the SCL annual report 2017-2018. Final update, based on final reporting for GTDB is expected in September 2019.

title.narrative: 2.2 Child labour and the community-based approach in particular remains high on the agenda of the Dutch government and increasingly becomes a well-recognized approach by the EU.

description.narrative: 1 = Child labour is not included as specific priority in relevant policy documents 2 = Child labour is included as specific priority in relevant policy documents 3 = Child labour and the community based approach are included as specific priorities in relevant policy documents in the Netherlands 4 = Child labour and the community based approach are again included as specific priority in relevant policy documents in the Netherlands of the new government and is included in informal and formal dialogue and/or formal policy papers at EU level.

comment.narrative: The Stop Child Labour Coalition was very happy to see the issue of child labour mentioned specifically in the coalition agreement of the new Dutch government that started in October, 2017. Final update, based on final reporting for GTDB is expected in September 2019.

title.narrative: International and national companies and CSR initiatives have improved their policies and practices to prevent and eliminate (risks of) child labour in their supply chains (preferably using the CLFZ approach)

1.1 Number of new (inter)national companies and/or CSR initiatives that have improved their practices by implementing activities and strategies towards the elimination of child labour and improving worker’s rights.

description.narrative: This indicator refers only to formal companies and CSR initiatives.

comment.narrative: 2 companies in the gold mining area in Mali and 2 companies in the natural stone sector in India. Final update, based on final reporting for GTDB is expected in September 2019.

title.narrative: 1.3 Number of child labour free zones that have been created and/or strengthened and expanded together with companies in the areas natural stone, coffee, footwear, gold, garment and seeds.

comment.narrative: 5 CLFZ projects have been started up: 1) CLFZ in the coffee sector with NGO Ceford in Uganda; 2) CLFZ in the garment sector with NGO SAVE in India; 3&4) CLFZ in the natural stone sector with NGO Manjari and workers union BWI in India; 5) CLFZ not linked to a specific sector with the Indian Teachers Union in India. So far a total of 3,929 children have been identified as out of school children in those 5 projects of which 1,799 children up to date have been prevented from dropping out of school or withdrawn from child labour and mainstreamed back in formal schools. For more information see the SCL Annual Report 2017-2018. Final update, based on final reporting for GTDB is expected in September 2019.

title.narrative: 1.4 Number of research/reviews published and distributed on child labour in selected sectors and areas to gain further insight as well as documented and published best practices from own experiences
